channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kerry Says U.S. to Review Its Approach to Mideast Talks
item.description: Declaring that it was “reality check time,” Secretary of State John Kerry said he would confer with President Obama about whether to continue its effort to break an impasse between Israeli and Palestinian negotiators.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Journalist Killed by Afghan Police Officer
item.description: An Associated Press photographer was killed and a reporter was wounded on Friday when an officer opened fire while they were sitting in a car.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and FAROOQ JAN MANGAL

item.title: Pakistani Taliban Extend Cease-Fire After Release of Prisoners
item.description: The group said the extension was meant to let the Pakistani government show its intent on carrying peace talks forward.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Western Journalist Killed in Afghanistan
item.description: A veteran Associated Press photographer was killed and a reporter was wounded on Friday when an Afghan policeman opened fire while they were sitting in their car in eastern Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Faithful Rush to Protect Church With a Cross Deemed Too Tall
item.description: Thousands of Christians gathered in eastern China at their newly built church to guard it from a forced demolition ordered by government officials.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: More Women on Company Boards Reduces Fraud, Study Finds
item.description: A study of securities fraud cases in China has found they were less likely to occur in companies where more women were on the board, leading the authors to recommend more gender diversity on boards around the world.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A woman walks in front of the IFC tower in the financial district of Hong Kong.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Residential Building Collapses in Zhejiang Province
item.description: A residential building of 40 apartments partially collapsed Friday morning in Fenghua city, eastern China, with 15 apartments reduced to rubble, according to the local government.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: South Korea Tests Missile That Can Strike Most of North
item.description: The launching by South Korea comes after Pyongyang conducted a series of its own missile tests, raising tensions on the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sensors Dispatched to Look for Missing Plane’s ‘Black Boxes’
item.description: Ships from Britain and Australia were deployed with technology that can detect pings from Malaysia Flight 370’s flight data recorders.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chasing the Money for Families of Passengers on Missing Flight
item.description: As the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 continues, Monica R. Kelly, an aviation accident attorney for Ribbeck Law based in Chicago, has been meeting with the families of the missing passengers to discuss compensation and, at times, act as a counselor.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monica R. Kelly and other members of her firm, Ribbeck Law, based in Chicago, have been meeting with the families of passengers on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: India Ink: Outsourcing Security as Bangalore’s Police Force Shrinks
item.description: Bangalore is teeming with private guards, but the city police are a far less noticeable presence.
item.category: Life and Love in the New Bangalore
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI

item.title: Hunt for Jet’s Black Boxes Is a Race Against Time
item.description: Only days are left before the batteries on the flight data and cockpit voice recorders on the missing Malaysia Airlines jet are set to die.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: A crew member abord a Royal New Zealand Air Force flight holds a canister to launch a GPS marker buoy so an object in the ocean be tracked by satellite in the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet.

item.title: U.S. Says It Tried to Build a Social Media Site in Cuba, but Failed
item.description: The Obama administration insists that the effort to create a Twitter-like network was intended to encourage political discussion, not to foment rebellion.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Zoo Teams Up to Highlight Animal Mistreatment at Shows
item.description: Animals Asia Foundation has found an unlikely host for its latest exhibition highlighting cruelty to animals in performances.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: A poster by Chen Zhikun and Su Guangsheng from an exhibition in Beijing designed to highlight the cruelty of animal performances.

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Airstrikes in Gaza Follow Militants’ Rocket Attacks
item.description: Israeli military aircraft carried out multiple airstrikes in the Gaza Strip early Friday, the Israeli military and Palestinian officials said, after militants fired four rockets into southern Israel late Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Karzai Is Trying to Keep His Sway After Term Ends
item.description: Those hoping to see Afghanistan’s president slip into a quiet retirement may be disappointed in the months to come.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Despite any ill will, American officials are still counting on President Hamid Karzai to help mediate what is expected to be a messy transition in Afghanistan.

item.title: Iraqi Envoy Calls on U.S. to Strengthen Relationship
item.description: The ambassador, Lukman Faily, said that the United States should be more generous in providing assistance but emphasized he did not advocate a resumed military presence.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: A Village Stadium Is a Symbol of Power for Hungary’s Premier
item.description: Viktor Orban, the country’s prime minister, has been aggressive both politically and in the business world, and a new soccer stadium in his tiny hometown is testament to his rising ambitions.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new soccer stadium in Felcsut, Hungary, is convenient for Viktor Orban, the prime minister: The house at right is his.

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: 4 Soldiers Killed in Chechnya
item.description: Four Russian servicemen were killed and seven were wounded when a bomb hit their vehicle in the North Caucasus republic of Chechnya, Russia’s Interior Ministry said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: Illness Spreads at Factories
item.description: Scores of garment workers have fallen sick this week at factories in Cambodia, including two that produce clothing for the sportswear groups Puma and Adidas, workers and the companies said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: China: U.S. to Shun Joint Naval Drills
item.description: The United States will not send a fleet to take part in naval exercises that China is hosting this month, military officials said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: World Briefing: Spain: Migrants Thwarted at Enclave
item.description: Spanish and Moroccan police on Thursday thwarted a new attempt by at least 100 African migrants to scale border fences and enter the Spanish enclave of Melilla.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Israel Cancels Prisoner Release as Talks Hit Impasse
item.description: The decision was a response to a Palestinian push to join 15 international conventions and treaties, which Israel regarded as an unacceptable move.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Chad, Amid Criticism, Will Pull Troops From Force in Central Africa
item.description: The decision came after criticism that Chadian soldiers were siding with Muslim militias against Christians fighting a bloody sectarian conflict.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Mexico City Journal: With Instruments and Odes, Comforting Mexican Mourners
item.description: The Wolves of the Sierra, musicians who play songs at funerals in Mexico City, are part of a tradition of hiring musicians to celebrate the dead.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
